title: George W. Bush
deleted: Bush opened the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] in Salt Lake City, Utah. Departing from previous practice, he stood among a group of U.S. athletes rather than from a ceremonial stand or box, saying: "On behalf of a proud, determined, and grateful nation, I declare open the Games of Salt Lake City, celebrating the Olympic Winter Games."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2002/02/20020209-2.html |title=President Bush Opens 2002 Olympic Games |date=February 8, 2002 |access-date=June 23, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514195905/http://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2002/02/20020209-2.html |archive-date=May 14, 2011 |via=[[NARA|National Archives]] |work=[[whitehouse.gov]] |url-status=dead }}</ref> In 2008, in the course of a good-will trip to Asia, he attended the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]] in Beijing.<ref>{{cite news |date=August 22, 2008 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/id/26131736 |title=Bush: Olympics exceeded my expectations |agency=Associated Press }}</ref>

Bush twice invoked [[Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution#Section 3: President's declaration of inability|Section{{nbs}}3 of the Twenty-fifth Amendment]], which allows a president to temporarily transfer the powers and duties of his office to the vice president, who then becomes [[Acting President of the United States|acting president]]. On June 29, 2002, Bush underwent a [[colonoscopy]] and invoked the provision, making Vice President Cheney the acting president. Bush was awake and resumed his presidential powers after two hours. On July 21, 2007, Bush again invoked the provision in preparation for another colonoscopy. Again, Bush resumed his presidential powers after two hours.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/acting_presidents.php |title=Acting Presidents Under the 25th Amendment |publisher=American Presidency Project |access-date=November 14, 2014}}</ref>
